text: today we're going to talk about
reactions and their yield now the amount
of product produced when all the
reactants are completely used up in
other words when our reaction run to
completion is known as the theoretical
yield note that most reactions don't
actually run to completion and that's
because our reactions usually reach
equilibrium before any of the reactants
are depleted and that means that
theoretical yield will not be possible
we'll get a number below theoretical
yield and this number is known as the
actual yield of our experiment now to
see how far a reaction proceeded in
other words how close it got to our
federal yield we simply find actually
ill and theoretical yield we divide two
so actual yield divided by theoretical
yield multiply that by 100 to get our
percent because otherwise this guy is a
fraction and that will give you percent
yield now let's look at the following
reaction so in the following reaction
one mole of methane reacts with two
moles of oxygen to produce one mole of
carbon dioxide and two moles of water
now let's suppose we react one mole of
methane with two moles of oxygen and we
find that our actual yield in grams was
38 grams of carbon dioxide now if we
find out a theoretical yield we could
then find our percent yield how would we
go about finding out their radical yield
well we have to realize that we have one
mole reacting with two moles that means
if theoretical yield of this guy is one
mole because one to two he gives you one
of this guy in two of this guy and one
mole of carbon dioxide is simply well we
take out a molecular weight of our
carbon dioxide which is 12 grams per
mole for carbon dioxide and 32 grams per
mole for two oxygens and we get 32 plus
12 gives us 44 grams per mole this is
our molecular weight of carbon dioxide
so you multiply by one mole and we get
the theoretical yield is 44 grams of
carbon dioxide so now we follow our
formula we take our 38 grams our actual
yield that we found from the experiment
divide that by our 44 grams our
theoretical yield this guy multiply that
by 100% to find a percentage and we find
that our percent yield is 86 point four
percent in other words this is a pretty
good yield because we see that our
actual yield is not too far off from our
theoretical yield anything 80 percent or
above is considered to be a good yield
